    \textbf{Abstract} \\[0.5cm]
    \begin{minipage}{0.9\textwidth}
        \small
        \singlespacing
        How does NGO-led public goods provision shift state incentives to provide public goods? When NGOs provide public goods, they may relieve the state of responsibility, provoke competition, or create space for more efficient governance. This paper theorizes how factors like the degree of political attribution and institutional budgetary constraints shape how state actors respond to NGO-provided public goods. In low-oversight settings, NGOs are more likely to act as a monetary windfall. Where budgetary constraints are tighter or attribution is clearer, NGOs may instead incentivize state capacity investments through more efficient spending or trigger political competition, respectively. To test these competing explanations, I compile panel data (2002–2022) on NGO activity, municipal expenditures, and municipal employment records in Brazil, where an efficiency effect or nonstate windfall is most likely ex ante, and apply a generalized difference-in-differences design. I find evidence for an efficiency effect: municipalities that receive NGO-provided public goods increase the hiring of civil service bureaucrats and reduce reliance on temporary contracts. Contrary to windfall or competition-based expectations, I find no evidence that NGO-provided goods significantly shift spending on public goods. These findings suggest that in settings with existing state capacity, NGOs can strengthen, rather than substitute, state capacity investments by changing how politicians allocate resources. This contributes to our understanding of the second-order political effects of nonstate service delivery, with broader implications for development and governance.
    \end{minipage}
